ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The course description for the course does not detail what taking the course is actually like. If I wanted to take this course, I would definitely talk to a student who had taken it before. I would tell the student if you want to be knowledgeable about the history and scholarship of icon studies, you should definitely take this course. I would also tell the student about the added work of putting together an online icon exhibition, both inside and outside of class time. That is the one thing I wish I could have better understood at the beginning of the semester, about how much continuous work the exhibition tookthroughout the semester.

I would say it was an excellent introduction to icons, but because of the exhibition project it came to be considerably more work than I had anticipated or budgeted for. Still, now that the exhibition is taking shape, I'm getting very excited about its potential.

I'd absolutely recommend this class, and describe it as a collaborative means of exploring icons through the practical format of an exhibition. I thought the project gave a really excellent and meaningful shape to the class. However, the logistics and planning involved was often overwhelming and frustrating. I think the entire group often feltin over their heads in ways which detracted from learning about icons. In the future, a more concrete plan and schedule is needed. However, I was amazed at the way everything came together at the end, and attribute this in part to a wonderful group of people, and in part to Professor Nelson's expertise. While this comment will probably give away my identity, I did not find the workload to be fair: those who worked on exhibition essays ended up with FAR more work than those who did catalog entries. This was frustrating at times. However, I learned a lot from my project and was very glad to have participated. I also LOVED our class trip to Washington DC and thought Professor Nelson did an absolutely perfect job of planning and running it.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I knew nothing of icons to begin with, and now I feel I have a pretty solid foundation in them. I LOVED this area and wish I had the language skills to make it my outside field. I was completely bowled over by how crucial this field is for any area of art historical study in the west. Everyone should have to take a class on eastern Christianity.
